title: 'The View' Host Sunny Hostin Confronts John Fetterman on Voting to Reopen Government: 'Why Bring a Butter Knife to a Gunfight?'
body:
"You had momentum. Why give in now?" the ABC host asks the Democratic senator

Senator John Fetterman was one of the handful of Democrats who opted to vote alongside Republicans to reopen the government over the weekend, and during his Tuesday appearance on "The View," host Sunny Hostin called him out directly for it. According to the ABC host, he and his colleagues brought "a butter knife to a gunfight."

Hostin was quick to point out that fellow Democrats like Sen. Bernie Sanders called the move a "horrific mistake," while California governor Gavin Newsom called it "pathetic" and a "surrender. The ABC host also questioned the decision following Democrats' sweeping victories on election night last Tuesday.

"Poll after poll found more Americans on both sides of the aisle blaming Republicans. Even Marjorie Taylor Greene blamed the GOP!" Hostin said. "As you mentioned, Democrats had big wins last week. So you had momentum. Why give in now? Why bring a butter knife to a gunfight?!"

On Sunday, Fetterman and nine other Democrats teamed with Republicans on a deal, despite the rest of the Democratic party remaining steadfast against it until Republicans agreed not to strip ACA subsidies from millions of people. Instead, Republicans simply promised to vote on the health care issue, but did not set a date for that vote, or promise that the subsidies would actually remain intact.

"Are you willing to gamble that the GOP will negotiate on health care in good faith once the government reopens?" Hostin pressed. "Because if that gamble is wrong, half a million Pennsylvanians, that you represent, their health care costs will skyrocket if you are wrong! And I believe you are wrong!"

For his part, Fetterman maintained his calm and immediately dismissed the idea of ever taking any cues from Marjorie Taylor Greene.

"If Democrats are celebrating Crazy Pants like that, then that's on them," he said. "And I don't need a lecture from, whether it's Bernie or the governor in California, because they are representing very deep blue kinds of populations. And a lot of those things were part of the extreme."

Fetterman argued against leaning extremely to one side, considering purple states like his.

title: Newsom at Brazil's COP30 Summit to Assure That California Is a 'Reliable Partner' on Climate
body:
BELEM, Brazil (Reuters) -California Governor Gavin Newsom has arrived in the Amazon city of Belem with a message for the COP30 summit: his state will continue to be a "reliable partner" on climate policy and green technology despite Washington's abandonment of the effort.

A strident political foe of U.S. President Donald Trump, Newsom has for months been teasing a run for the White House in 2028. On Tuesday and Wednesday, he is expected to meet with officials from some of the 195 governments attending this year's U.N. climate negotiations.

He has planned meetings with a series of subnational leaders, including the governor of Brazil's state of Para, the location of the summit.

Though California is just one of 50 U.S. states, its economy is the world's fourth-largest - making it a key player in influencing markets and energy policy.

"The reason I'm here is in the absence of leadership coming from the United States," he said at an investors summit in Brazil's financial hub of Sao Paulo on Monday. "This vacuum, it's rather jaw-dropping."

Newsom has touted California's embrace of green tech, highlighting that the state has seven times more renewable energy jobs than fossil fuel jobs and reminding people that EV giant Tesla was founded in California. This is in sharp contrast to Washington's climate denial and determination to boost global use of polluting fossil fuels.

Newsom also lamented the U.S. rollback on clean energy policy as ceding the fast-growing green-tech market to China.

"China gets it," Newsom told investors. "United States is toast competitively if we don't wake up to what the hell they're doing in this space, on supply chains, how they're dominating manufacturing, how they're flooding the zone here, EU, elsewhere, Africa."

China not only dominates the markets for electric vehicles, renewable energy components and batteries, he said, but it also leads in software while U.S. automakers like General Motors are "trying to recreate the 19th century," Newsom said. GM recently slowed its production of EVs.

The United States has conspicuously snubbed this year's COP30 summit, with Trump falsely declaring climate change a hoax.

Some diplomats worried that Trump's Republican administration might try to disrupt the summit from afar.

Newsom, a Democrat, said last month that he is mulling a presidential run in 2028. He has started to parrot Trump's brash style of messaging on social media.

Last week, California voters backed his proposal to redraw the state's voting districts to offset redistricting in other states aimed at boosting the number of congressional seats held by Republicans.

Newsom told investors in Sao Paulo that Trump was emulating Russia and Saudi Arabia in turning the United States into a "petro state" and embracing Chinese-style "state capitalism" over the free market. He criticized Trump's aggressive tariff policies as "madness from an investment perspective."

"I feel like it's modeled a little bit on President Xi, not President Reagan. The hell's going on?" he said.

(Reporting by Valerie Volcovici in Belem, Brazil; Editing by Katy Daigle and Matthew Lewis)

title: Trump administration skips COP30 climate summit, leaving California's Newsom to hurl criticism from Brazil
body:
Ramy Inocencio is a CBS News foreign correspondent based in London, covering Europe and the Middle East. He joined the Network in 2019 as CBS News' Asia correspondent, based in Beijing and reporting across the Asia-Pacific, bringing two decades of experience working and traveling between Asia and the United States.

In Belm, the bustling Brazilian gateway to the Amazon rainforest, leaders from nearly 200 nations have gathered for the United Nations' 30th Climate Change Conference, known as COP30, to chart difficult next steps in the global fight against climate change. But the absence of the leaders from the world's three largest greenhouse gas emitters -- China, the United States and India -- cast a shadow over the summit as it kicked off.

Beijing and New Delhi did dispatch senior-level delegations for the two-week summit. The White House, however, said no high-level U.S. officials would attend this year's COP. President Trump has repeatedly dismissed human-caused climate change as "a hoax."

Two Democratic governors, California's Gavin Newsom and New Mexico's Michelle Lujan Grisham, were in Brazil to attend the summit, representing state-level U.S. efforts to curb emissions.

"What the hell is going on here?" Newsom asked at a global investors' summit in So Paulo on Monday, where he fired off a characteristic criticism of the Trump administration. "We're in Brazil -- one of our great trading partners, one of the world's great democracies. Home to all the rare earth metals we need. This is the country we should be engaging with, not slapping with 50% tariffs."

Ten years ago, 195 nations taking part in the COP21 summit signed onto the landmark Paris Agreement, intended to commit individual nations to take measures that, collectively, would limit the rise in average global temperatures to "well below" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit). The objective in the agreement, which the Obama administration signed, was to pursue efforts to cap the global temperature increase at 1.5C (2.7F) above pre-industrial levels.

That target now appears out of reach.

Based on national plans submitted this year, the planet is on course to warm by roughly 2.5C (4.5F) during this century. The Earth's average surface temperature in 2024 was the hottest since record keeping began in 1880 -- and the last 10 years have all ranked among the warmest ever observed.

Still, U.N. Climate Change Executive Secretary Simon Stiell told delegates in Brazil this week that after three decades of dedicated talks, "we are now bending the curve of planet heating emissions downwards -- for the very first time."

"I am not sugarcoating it," Stiell hastened to add. "We have so much more work to do."

A new U.N. analysis released this week shows that, if current national commitments are met, global emissions should fall by about 12% by 2035 compared to 2019 levels. That's an improvement from last month's projection of 10%, but still far short of the 60% reduction scientists say would be needed to keep warming within the Paris Agreement's 1.5C goal.

U.N. Secretary-General Antnio Guterres has been pressing for stronger action, warning that surpassing the 1.5C limit now looks almost inevitable and slamming it as both a "moral failure" and "deadly negligence" putting the lives of billions of people at risk.

Despite low expectations for any sweeping breakthroughs, the delegations at COP30 are broadly expected to update national commitments to curb emissions in the next decade.

A Brazil-led initiative to raise $125 billion for rainforest protection, coupled with renewed scrutiny of fossil fuel companies -- which Guterres accused of "holding back change" while collecting record profits and government subsidies -- were also expected to come out of the two-week gathering.

There is also likely to be more pressure applied on the governments of wealthy nations to help finance climate adaptations around the world, to help developing countries mitigate the impacts of a warming planet.

At last year's COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan, countries agreed on an aspirational goal of mobilizing $1.3 trillion annually by 2035, with at least $300 billion expected to come from developing economies.

Publicly available data on how much climate finance has actually been delivered since then, however, remains scarce, and that could be a key point of contention for the negotiators gathered in Belm to discuss.

title: Newsom Says Trump Gave 'Middle Finger' to Brazil over Tariffs
body:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) scolded President Donald Trump on Monday for giving Brazil "the middle finger" by daring to impose tariffs on the South American nation.

Newsom, speaking at a Milken Institute event in So Paulo ahead of the COP30 climate doomer summit, lashed out at Trump for not participating in the conference hosted by the Brazilian government at the city of Belm.

"The hell's going on in my country? Not one person from the administration. Show any respect to any of you. Forget politics. Disrespect. We're in Brazil. One of our great trading partners. One of the world's great democracies," Newsom said.

"I mean, hell, home to all the -- you need rare earth minerals. This is the country we should be engaging in. Instead, middle finger with 50 percent tariffs. That's shameful. Forgive me. That's an aside. Sorry," he continued.

Newsom is presently visiting Brazil and is expected to travel to Belm this Tuesday to participate in COP30. The California governor told Politico he and his team were getting a "disproportionate number of calls" to meet on the sidelines of the event.

Like many other international heads of state, Trump did not attend last week's COP30 Summit hosted by leftist President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, a two-day presidential gathering that served as an opening event to the broader series of COP30-related activities that will run in Belm through Friday, November 21.

The United States government did not send any high-level representative to the ongoing climate doom conference. Newsom told Politico that "not even a note taker" was sent by the U.S. government.

"We're at peak influence because of the flatness of the surrounding terrain with the Trump administration and all the anxiety," Newson reportedly asserted.

RELATED: Zeldin -- Newsom and Bass "Need to Get Off of Their Asses" and Rebuild from L.A. Fires

Politico reported in addition to holding meetings with German and Chilean representatives, Newsom is expected to give plenary remarks and will then visit the Amazon rainforest to meet with indigenous communities.

Asked by Brazilian press on whether he would run for president, Newsom answered, "Nothing else matters but 2026 and taking back the House of Representatives."

In July, President Trump signed an executive order identifying Brazil as a national security threat and imposed a 50 percent tariff on the country, citing the political persecution of conservative former President Jair Bolsonaro and the numerous acts of persecution and censorship committed by Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes.

De Moraes and other members of the top court sentenced Bolsonaro to 27 years in prison for "crimes against democracy."

At press time, the court has not determined which reclusion center Bolsonaro will serve the sentence at. The former president, presently under a strict house arrest, was diagnosed with skin cancer in August. After months of continued refusal, Lula finally met with Trump in late October to discuss tariffs.

title: Newsom and Mamdani stake out starring roles on the left
body:
OPPOSITES ATTRACT -- Gavin Newsom and Zohran Mamdani are the new stars on the left in America -- an odd pairing of a governor who occasionally pivots to the center and a mayor-elect who embraces socialism.

The two hadn't even communicated until Election Day, but since then, Newsom and Mamdani have been bound together as two of the most prominent figures in the Democratic Party -- representing the poles in a party divided over ideology and that no longer has a clear national leader.

As Jeremy B. White, Nick Reisman and Camille von Kaenel report this morning, their differences are stark. Newsom has been the establishment-sanctioned favorite in every race since he emerged from San Francisco's centrist ranks, infuriating his party's left flank at times on issues like tech regulation and transgender rights. Mamdani, a democratic socialist, not only came from outside the political hierarchy but stunned New York kingmakers by riding an affordability platform to victory.

But for all their differences, the two represent a shift in Democratic politics: combativeness coupled with a savvy for modern campaigning and a return to the antagonistic posture that powered Democrats at the opening of Donald Trump's first term.

"Voters are looking for people who represent the exact opposite of what appear to be strategic, thoughtful, overly political, overly insidery approaches," said Evan Roth Smith, a Democratic strategist and pollster. "Newsom and Mamdani represent a repudiation of the practice of politics that the Democratic Party has become accustomed to."

Now, the two are bashing the Trump administration from opposite coasts. Their recent wins -- Newsom on redistricting and Mamdani in the mayoral race -- have some Democrats fantasizing over the idea of re-building a big tent.

"It shows the breadth of the party that these two people came out of election night as the big winners," said Katie Merrill, a California-based Democratic consultant, arguing the outcome showcased two different directions for the party: "the Mamdani way," responding to Trump and MAGA by going as far left as possible, or "the Newsom way," which is more strategic and establishment-friendly.

Read the full story on how Newsom and Mamdani are reshaping politics.

GOOD MORNING. Happy Tuesday. Thanks for waking up with Playbook.

Like what you're reading? Sign up to get California Playbook in your inbox, and forward it to a friend. You can also text us at 916-562-0685 -- save it as "CA Playbook" in your contacts. Or drop us a line at [email protected] and [email protected], or on X -- @DustinGardiner and @jonesblakej.

WHERE'S GAVIN? In Brazil attending COP.

CANDIDATE SPRINGS ANEW -- Democrat Marc Iannarino, a bartender and Navy veteran who lives in Palm Springs, is running for Rep. Darrell Issa's spot in Congress.

He's entering the crowded race for the 48th District, which Proposition 50 turned from Republican-slanted to a competitive contest with the aim of electing a Democrat. Issa has not announced his 2026 plans, but could run in that district or against fellow GOP incumbent Reps. Ken Calvert and Young Kim for a newly safe red seat.

Iannarino in an interview ahead of his launch criticized Issa for health care spending votes as he touted his working-class roots and said he's "not interested" in accepting corporate PAC money.

"My family and my friends would be upset at me if I passed laws to raise the price of health care, if I passed laws that allowed tariffs," Iannarino said.

But it was President Donald Trump's deployment of National Guard members to U.S. cities that ultimately pushed Iannarino to run for office, he said. "Watching troops used to intimidate citizens, well, that was a major red line for me."

SOCAL SHUFFLE -- Democratic Rep. Linda Snchez confirmed Monday -- as was widely expected -- that she's running in the new, now safely Democratic 41st District drawn by Prop 50. Within hours, Pico Rivera Councilmember Monica Snchez entered the race for the nearby 38th District, which Linda Snchez is vacating, with the representative's endorsement.

That tees up a Dem-on-Dem contest for the new, solidly blue 38th between Monica Snchez and Los Angeles County Supervisor Hilda Solis, who has been running since August in anticipation of the gerrymander succeeding. Solis has drawn support from Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass and Reps. Judy Chu, Lou Correa, Laura Friedman, Robert Garcia and Luz Rivas, while Rep. Norma Torres and several local mayors have endorsed Monica Snchez.

FIRST IN PLAYBOOK: LEANING MOD -- Rep. Zoe Lofgren is endorsing moderate Assemblymember Jasmeet Bains over progressive Visalia school board member Randy Villegas as the two Democrats compete to challenge Republican Rep. David Valadao in the Central Valley. Valadao's district, already a battleground, will become more competitive for Democrats under Prop 50 and is one of the five districts the measure targeted.

PELOSI PIVOT -- Christine Pelosi said Monday that she will run for a California state Senate seat, passing on a campaign for the House seat held for decades by her mother, former Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

The younger Pelosi, an attorney and veteran party organizer, had long been considered a potential successor to her mother, who announced last week that she's not running for another term next year. Nancy Pelosi's impending retirement has set off a cascade of maneuvering in the city as Democrats seize on the rare opening, but in a video posted online Monday, her daughter said her sights were set on Sacramento instead.

"I'm running to represent you, San Francisco, in Sacramento," she said in a video posted on social media. "What do we do when our freedoms are under attack? We speak up, we fight back and we organize. Power for the people."

TURNING POINT AT BERKELEY -- The final stop on Turning Point USA's fall college tour following the assassination of its founder, Charlie Kirk, drew over 150 protesters to UC Berkeley on Monday night, by campus estimates. Outside Zellerbach Hall, demonstrators of the conservative youth organization shouted chants like "No Trump, no KKK, no fascist USA" and displayed a giant sign that read "TPUSA Out Of The Bay," Eric He reported from campus.

The protests and clashes outside provided a foil for the event's speakers, who cast the dissent as an attempt to crack down on discourse. "I'd like to thank Antifa for the welcoming," said comedian Rob Schneider, one of the headline speakers.

INJECTING A RIFT -- Labor's yearslong campaign against community clinics in the Legislature and on the ballot is now bleeding into the governor's race.

After Playbook reported that the clinics' California Primary Care Association Advocates endorsed former Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra, state Superintendent Tony Thurmond called on him to reject the organization's backing while calling it "anti-labor."

Thurmond's camp pointed to a fact sheet on the clinics' website that called a SEIU-UHW-backed ballot measure "a shameful power play by SEIU-UHW executives who are weaponizing the ballot measure process to force their demands."

"It's unacceptable that the California Primary Care Association Advocates' website is openly attacking healthcare workers and their union SEIU UHW, engaging in fear-mongering and misleading the public," Thurmond said in a statement. "I won't stand for it, and neither should Xavier Becerra."

SEIU pushed a bill this year to place restrictions on how clinics can spend their budgets, and then SEIU-UHW put a similar proposal forward as a 2026 ballot measure.

Thurmond, trailing Becerra and others in polls and fundraising, will likely need labor spending to make his campaign competitive. He called on Becerra to go further and disavow the union's support, but Becerra did not oblige.

"Considering last week's favorable Berkeley IGS poll, pivotal endorsements from the Laborers union and California's community health centers, and Secretary Becerra's extensive record of taking on and beating the Trump Administration, it's no surprise candidates are lining up to take a swing at him -- it's clear that Xavier Becerra is now the candidate to beat in this race," a spokesperson for his campaign said, referencing a recent poll that showed Becerra trailing only former Rep. Katie Porter on the Democratic side.

Francisco Silva, the president and CEO of the clinics group, only reiterated his support for Becerra in response, saying, "CPCA Advocates will always stand for patients, no matter the politics. And we support those who share that value."

Meanwhile, Becerra added another endorser, Rep. Gil Cisneros, who said in a statement that the former representative's background on the Hill, in the Biden administration and the California attorney general's office "has prepared him to move our state toward a stronger, healthier future."

-- with help from Rachel Bluth

GET IN LINE -- The hottest ticket at the UN climate talks kicking off in Brazil might just be a meeting with Newsom, our Camille von Kaenel writes from So Paulo.

Newsom couldn't walk halfway down a hallway Monday without fielding requests for a meeting -- or a selfie. One Brazilian picture-taker had him repeat the Portuguese word for "Let's go": "Vamos." His first question from the Brazilian press on Monday: whether he would run for president ("Nothing else matters but 2026 and taking back the House of Representatives," he said). Read more from last night's California Climate on Newsom's hero's welcome -- and what awaits him at the talks kicking off in Belm on Tuesday.

LATINO VOTER POWER -- While ballots are still being counted, it appears that Prop 50 will earn a significantly higher share of the vote than Kamala Harris did in California last fall. The San Francisco Chronicle ran statistical tests on the returns, and found that:

"No demographic factor better correlated with the difference in support between Prop 50 and Harris than the Latino share of a county's population. That is, the more Latino a county, the more it appears to have swung in favor of Prop 50. The less Latino -- and the whiter -- a county, the likelier it was to have supported Prop 50 by less than it did Harris."

PET CEMETERY -- San Francisco Supervisor Isabella "Beya" Alcaraz, whom Mayor Daniel Lurie recently appointed, previously owned a pet store that reportedly was left in a state of squalor. As The San Francisco Standard reports, the current owner of the store alleges that she found hundreds of dead mice and "dozens of deceased pets" stored in a freezer.

The Standard said Alcaraz did not respond to questions about her business, and instead released a statement: "Our small businesses are what makes the Sunset the best place to live," she said. "Any small business owner can tell you that running one isn't easy -- but since the day I took over, my goal has always been to ensure The Animal Connection could continue bringing joy to our community."

-- Assemblymember James Gallagher is still pushing a GOP-backed proposal to divide California into two states -- an effort he said Proposition 50 emboldens. (SF Gate)

-- Oakland Unified School District Superintendent Denise Saddler warned that the embattled district must make severe cuts to stay afloat. (The Mercury News)

-- The home at the center of a bribery scandal involving former Orange County Supervisor Andrew Do, who was sentenced to five years in prison, has sold for $1.1 million. (LAist)

WEDDING BELLS -- Heidi Sieck, co-founder at VoteProChoice, and Alex Tourk, principal at Ground Floor Public Affairs, announce their impending nuptials. The couple have been friends for 25 years and fell in love 3.5 years ago on Friday the 13th in New York City. They will have a private wedding ceremony with their children at Congregation Emanu-El officiated by Rabbi Ryan Bauer and a small celebration at Bix in San Francisco.

PEOPLE MOVES -- Bloom Energy has hired Sara O'Neill as vice president of policy and government affairs. She was previously on the executive leadership team at Aera Energy, LLC for six years.

BIRTHDAYS -- Malia Arenas, associate at ALZA Strategies ... former Sen. Barbara Boxer ... POLITICO's John Hendel ... Tucker Bounds ... Taylor Holgate ... Nathan Imperiale ... Leonardo DiCaprio ... Demi Moore ... Jon Hartley ...

BELATED B-DAY WISHES -- (was Monday): Raphael J. Sonenshein ... Ken Chasen

IN MEMORIAM -- Aquil Basheer, the former Black Panther known as "the Commander" who spent much of his life seeking to stop gang violence, has died, according to the Los Angeles Times.

WANT A SHOUT-OUT FEATURED? -- Send us a birthday, career move or another special occasion to include in POLITICO's California Playbook. You can now submit a shout-out using this Google form.

CALIFORNIA POLICY IS ALWAYS CHANGING: Know your next move. From Sacramento to Silicon Valley, POLITICO California Pro provides policy professionals with the in-depth reporting and tools they need to get ahead of policy trends and political developments shaping the Golden State. To learn more about the exclusive insight and analysis this subscriber-only service offers, click here.

Share your message with our influential readers to foster engagement and drive action. Contact Lynn Fine to find out how: [email protected].

title: Letters to the Editor: Newsom should lean on policy, not state symbolism, if he wants the presidency
body:
To the editor: If Gov. Gavin Newsom leans on California's symbolic image during a potential presidential campaign, it risks backfiring ("How can Newsom stay relevant? Become the new FDR," Nov. 9). While California's positions can be used to strategically highlight policy successes, its polarizing image can exacerbate alienation.

According to a 2024 survey for the Los Angeles Times, 50% of adults nationwide believe California is in decline. 48% of Republicans believe the state is "not really American." Despite Newsom's recent increase in the polls, leaning on California's symbolism is likely to continue alienating voters who view the state negatively.

The counterargument presented here by columnist Anita Chabria is that "regular people hate despair, poverty and Nazis far more than they hate California." That over-simplification fails to address voter concerns on national issues.

Popular or not, Newsom struggles to appeal to his critics. Rather than showcasing California as America's future, he should instead popularize his policy successes and advocate for uniform progress.

To the editor: I agree with columnist Mark Z. Barabak that affordability will be the key factor in the 2028 presidential election ("Newsom prevailed on Proposition 50. But the White House is still a big reach," Nov. 9). I like Newsom, but as a Michigan native, I'm certain that the inevitable opposition campaign ads showing gas, grocery and home prices in California will evoke shock in most of the country. As governor for eight years, Newsom will be seen as responsible for it.

To win, whoever the Democratic candidate is will have to tie affordability to reducing inequality. This would include increasing income and estate taxes on the wealthy in order to fund child care, tuition, medical coverage and housing assistance, the key components of the affordability crisis.

Newsom, who will be perceived as presiding over an unaffordable state, is simply the wrong messenger. It's too bad, because the right messenger will also need to project strength and Newsom certainly has that.

To the editor: Like Rodney Dangerfield, California just gets no respect. "Far left," "nutty," "secular," "permissive." Can we please dream up some new stereotypes? These are old, tired and worn out.

And "tax-happy"? Now that's rich coming from non-Californians. In the fiscal year 2023-24, California paid $806 billion in federal taxes, the largest amount of any state. California is a "donor state" because it contributes more in federal taxes than it receives back in federal funding.

And as for old, worn-out cliches, it's my turn: Ah, California, "can't live with her, can't live without her." Or, put another way, "don't bite the hand that feeds you."

title: Opinion | California's woes are many. Will any Democrat dare admit it in 2026?
body:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks to reporters in Stockton, California, on Oct. 22. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

Bill Whalen, the Hoover Institution's Virginia Hobbs Carpenter Distinguished Policy Fellow in Journalism, was chief speechwriter to former California governor Pete Wilson.

As tempting as it may be to view the New Jersey and Virginia gubernatorial votes as Democratic temperature checks, a more telling thermometer may exist farther west: the race to succeed a term limited Gov. Gavin Newsom in California.

This may seem odd given that the Golden State is arguably the most azure of America's "blue" states. Apart from Arnold Schwarzenegger, no Republican has won a California gubernatorial contest in more than three decades. The average Democratic margin of victory in the four post-Arnold races? Almost 19 points.

Yet, California's 2026 contest bears watching for two reasons: an uncharacteristically wide-open primary lacking a governor-in-waiting, which wasn't the case the last two times there was no incumbent on the ballot, and a bevy of Democratic hopefuls engaged in a balancing act of appealing to an electorate that believes the Golden State is on the wrong track while not holding their party at least partially responsible for that sour mood. (Democrats currently occupy all of California's statewide constitutional offices and enjoy supermajority control of both legislative chambers.)

About the California field: To the extent that there was a front-runner after former vice president Kamala Harris took herself out of the running, it was former congresswoman Katie Porter. But her lead always rested on the political quicksand of simple name recognition from having competed in last year's U.S. Senate primary. It remains to be seen what damage she has suffered from recent bad press regarding her temperament.

Who, then, to fill the void? At least three other Democrats -- all with flaws -- could jump in.

Sen. Alex Padilla may decide he wants to relocate to Sacramento, but he has little to show in the way of accomplishments since replacing Kamala Harris in Washington four years ago. (One September gubernatorial poll shows 7 percent support for California's senior U.S. senator.)

Climate investor Tom Steyer, who starred in self-financed and brutally anti-Trump ads in support of Proposition 50 and a mid-decade redrawing of California's congressional map, suddenly became front and center on voters' streaming devices. (Some local Democrats critiqued Steyer's late involvement as self-serving.) But his political record is notable for its futility: more than $150 million wasted on a failed presidential bid in 2020.

And there's Rick Caruso, the Los Angeles developer and billionaire who, judging from his social media feed, can't decide whether he wants to be the state's next governor or his city's next mayor. That Caruso was an 11th-hour party convert when he ran for mayor in 2022 is something his primary rivals will probably reference.

The gubernatorial primary isn't until June 2, which gives Democratic hopefuls about seven months to lay out policy agendas. But there's a catch: To land Newsom's current day job, those hopefuls have to work around a Newsom flaw -- his overpromising when applying for the same position.

Seven years ago, on the precipice of succeeding the more centrist Jerry Brown, Newsom vowed to steer California hard to port. In his words: "Guaranteed health care for all. A 'Marshall Plan' for affordable housing. A master plan for aging with dignity. A middle-class workforce strategy. A cradle-to-college promise for the next generation. An all-hands approach to ending child poverty."

With a year left in office, Newsom hasn't made good on that ambitious agenda. California's child poverty rate nearly tripled from 2021 to 2024. The goal of building 2.5 million homes by 2030 (downgraded from 3.5 million) won't be reached at the current pace. After expanding Medi-Cal (the state's Medicaid program) to include all Californians regardless of legal status, the latest state budget scaled back health care for undocumented immigrants -- a shift that speaks to the Golden State's fiscal woes and perhaps the governor's presidential ambitions.

Does this mean that, now that California has voted on the Trump referendum that was Proposition 50 and attention should turn back to conditions on the ground, a Golden State Democratic candidate might dare to disparage the governor's record? It would be a calculated risk -- calculating how to survive California's "open" primary, where the top two vote-getters advance to the general election regardless of party affiliation.

Designed to encourage candidates to reach out to the middle with a more centrist appeal, the opposite occurred in 2018's open primary when Newsom, well ahead in the polls, spent money attacking conservative John Cox to elevate the Republican to second place. By doing so, Newsom avoided a more competitive runoff against former Los Angeles mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, who is once again a gubernatorial candidate.

But in a field currently lacking a Democrat with the same standing that Newsom enjoyed seven years ago -- as lieutenant governor, he ramped up for higher office by championing successful ballot measures on gun control and marijuana legalization -- no Democrat is likely to approach his 33.7 percent share of the primary vote (Democrats account for more than 61 percent of the primary vote). Instead, each hopeful would have to figure out how to appeal to a California electorate among whom nearly 45 percent of registered voters identify as Democrat and 22.5 percent as independent.

Will Democrats campaign across California as Newsom did in 2018, offering a menu of unattainable progressive ideals? Will a viable Democratic candidate dare to say that their party has contributed to California's woes, including chronic homelessness, educational inequality and fiscal recklessness?

Perhaps the latter is only so much California dreaming. Still, in the state that's home to the country's entertainment capital, it would be nice to see a plot twist.

title: Trump Blasts Newsom as a 'Horrible Governor' After His Shutdown Deal Criticism: 'He's Gone Radical Left' | Video
body:
"If he ran the country like that, we would have an absolutely gonezo country," the president adds

Donald Trump made it clear he was not a fan of Gavin Newsom, blasting the California politician as a "horrible governor" in a new interview.

The president laid into California's governor during Monday's Fox News sit-down with Laura Ingraham, where he was asked to respond to Newsom's criticism of the recent government shutdown compromise.

After showing a clip of the governor accusing Democrat senators of rolling over and playing by the "old set of rules" to bring the government shut down to an end, Trump accused Newsom of going "radical left" with his beliefs.

"I knew Gavin for four years. I got along great with him. But he's gone radical left," Trump said. "You know, he's building a train system from San Francisco to L.A. that's got about a 2,000 or 3,000% cost overrun. It's the worst thing I've [ever seen]. I've never seen anything like it."

As Trump went on, he criticized Newsom's response to the wildfires that ravaged Southern California earlier this year.

"They lost 25,000 houses. Do you know they haven't issued one building permit yet? These people are trying to rebuild their houses," Trump claimed. However, per the Rebuilding LA website run by the California government, more 984 permits have been issued in the City of Los Angeles and 780 permits have been issued in the greater County of Los Angeles.

He continued: "He did something even worse than that. He's now taking a big section of [Pacific] Palisades or some area and he's going to build low-income housing where they used to have luxury housing ... his fire stuff is out of control."

While Trump noted that he "always liked [Newsom]," he slammed the California Democrat as "a horrible governor."

"If he ran the country like that, we would have an absolutely gonezo country," Trump added. "This country would be gone. The fact is, if I weren't president, if Kamala [Harris] got in, you wouldn't have $20 trillion coming in, you'd have money leaving."

At this point, Trump transitioned away from his criticism of Newsom and focused on the country's welfare system, including SNAP benefits.

"SNAP is supposed to be if you are down and out," he lamented. "That's what the purpose of it -- people walk in and they get it automatically now. So, the number is many times what it should be."

Watch more from Trump's interview with Ingraham above.

title: The hottest meeting in Brazil
body:
With help from Noah Baustin, Alex Nieves, Christa Marshall and Jennifer Yachnin

RUNNING ON BRAZILIAN COFFEE: Gov. Gavin Newsom isn't even at the United Nations climate talks yet -- but he's already getting bombarded with meeting requests.

Newsom kicked off his trip to Brazil 1,800 miles south of the Amazonian city of Belm that's hosting this year's international gathering, talking to Brazilian and American financiers at an investors' summit in So Paulo.

His first question from the Brazilian press on Monday: whether he would run for president ("Nothing else matters but 2026 and taking back the House of Representatives," he said). Newsom couldn't walk halfway down a hallway without fielding a meeting request from CEOs and NGOs -- or a selfie request. One Brazilian picture-taker had him repeat the Portuguese word for "Let's go": "Vamos."

His remarks to investors at the Milken Global Investors' Symposium sounded more like a campaign rally than a business speech.

"We have seen this complete reversal of so much of the progress that the Biden administration made," he said. "What Trump is doing is unprecedented in American history. ... This should not be through the lens or prism of red, in American vernacular, versus blue."

Then he held an hour-long round table with representatives from major investment funds, philanthropies, development banks and energy leaders, who he said pushed him to bolster economic ties in existing voluntary agreements with Brazilian governments.

Newsom told POLITICO he and his team were getting a "disproportionate number of calls" to meet on the sidelines of the talks, where the U.S. government's delegation numbers zero ("not even a note taker," Newsom said.)

"We're at peak influence because of the flatness of the surrounding terrain with the Trump administration and all the anxiety," Newsom said in an interview in So Paulo.

Newsom is playing a well-rehearsed role for California, which has staked out a leading role in international climate diplomacy for decades under both Democratic and Republican governors, including during President Donald Trump's first term.

The Trump administration's dismantling of climate policies to favor oil and gas interests only give California more space to fill, said former Gov. Jerry Brown, who got a hero's welcome himself at the United Nations climate talks in 2017, the first year of Trump 1.0.

"Trump, he's saying one thing," Brown said in an interview. "Newsom is saying something else, very important." The impact, he said, will be determined in Belm. "That's why it's exciting. There's not an answer yet."

That gives Newsom an opening -- and a risk. Where Brown led a coalition of states eager to demonstrate continued commitment on climate in Trump's first term, Newsom will arrive in Belm, near the mouth of the Amazon River, at a time when U.S. politics are tilting rightward and even Democrats are pulling back on embracing climate policies.

And there's little Newsom's team, which includes ex-State Department climate negotiators, can actually do in the closed-door talks reserved for countries. But the governor's goal is to influence from just outside the door.

"We're in every room, because California has been the inspiration for a lot of these jurisdictions," he told POLITICO.

Newsom's heading next to Belm, where he's scheduled to meet with other subnational leaders and renew environmental pacts with other countries and states -- starting on Tuesday with the environment ministers from Germany and the German state of Baden-Wrttemburg, which Brown first partnered with to promote the soft power of subnational governments during Trump's first term. Newsom said he would also meet with representatives from Chile. He's also expected to give plenary remarks at the U.N.

After that, he'll head deeper into the Amazon rainforest to meet with Indigenous communities on conservation -- one of the goals of the Brazilian organizers of the climate talks. Newsom said he saw the visit to the Amazon as a spiritual opportunity.

"It connects us to our creator," he said. "It connects us to thousands and thousands of generations." -- CvK

Did someone forward you this newsletter? Sign up here!

NUCLEAR NEWSOM: California's only nuclear power plant hit a relicensing snag last week at the Coastal Commission. But Newsom signaled on Monday that he remains bullish on the at-times-controversial source of energy.

The Golden State governor said during a fireside chat with Milken Institute CEO Rich Ditizio in Brazil that nuclear power has "entered the conversation" in California and across the U.S. "in a way that is surprising compared to where we were even five years ago."

"It's become more and more socialized, less weaponized, from the dynamic of being controversial now to being deeply part of our low carbon green growth strategy," Newsom said.

He reflected on his 2022 move to extend Diablo Canyon's operations to 2030, instead of allowing the plant to shutter.

"I thought it would end my term. My term was extended for 4 years," Newsom said (jokingly, he later clarified). "I give you that as a political proof point -- turns out not to have been as consequential as I thought." -- Cvk, NB

TICK TOCK: The Trump administration's deadline for state negotiators to land a Colorado River deal is here, but there's still no water sharing agreement on the table.

Scott Cameron, the Bureau of Reclamation's acting commissioner, set a Nov. 11 deadline for the seven states that share the river to hash out an initial deal, but there was little sign Monday that an agreement -- even one that is light on details -- is forthcoming, Jennifer Yachnin reports for POLITICO's E&E News.

That could put the Trump administration in the undesirable position of having to determine how to reduce water use by farmers and population centers across the West, a decision that would almost certainly trigger a Supreme Court fight.

The tensions spilled into public view last week, as Arizona Gov. Katie Hobbs blamed Colorado, Utah, Wyoming and New Mexico for holding up progress, arguing those states were refusing to commit to reducing water use while demanding cutbacks from Arizona, California and Nevada. -- AN

AI AND DRY: The U.S. data center boom could stress water supplies and spike carbon emissions through the end of the decade to the equivalent of adding 5 million to 10 million cars annually to U.S. roadways.

That's according to a peer-reviewed study published Monday, reports Christa Marshall for POLITICO's E&E News.

At the current rate of growth, U.S. data centers would add 24 million to 44 million metric tons of carbon dioxide annually to the atmosphere through the end of the decade, the study said. The build-out also is projected to drain 731 million to 1,125 million cubic meters of water per year, an amount equivalent to the household usage of 6 million to 10 million Americans.

The researchers developed an industry roadmap to lower its environmental impact by steering development to states like Texas, Nebraska, Montana and South Dakota that have low water stress and significant potential for low-carbon energy sources.

While California has abundant renewable energy resources, the often-parched state has some of the worst water scarcity issues in the nation, according to the study.

In other data center news, Newsom was asked Monday about a report that two major Santa Clara data center developments have been sitting empty, awaiting hookups to the local utility grid. He mostly dodged.

"I'm very proud, I'm also very humbled by all of these challenges," Newsom said. He added that the state improved its permitting and procurement strategies last year because he is "deeply mindful of the energy relationship to all this and where the energy is in terms of innovation and entrepreneurialism." -- CM, NB, CvK

ENERGY MOVES: A California legislative staffer is making the jump to a national energy business association.

Brandon Garca is joining Advanced Energy United, which represents energy and technology companies including Sunrun, NRG and Microsoft, as its California policy director. Garca spent the last five years as a staffer in the California Legislature, most recently as the legislative director for Sen. Eloise Gmez Reyes. He'll be focused on advancing policies that strengthen the state's advanced energy industry, Advanced Energy United spokesperson Caroline Grace said in a statement. -- NB

-- Deven Upadhyay, general manager of the nation's largest water district, discusses the challenges climate change poses to Southern California's aging water infrastructure.

-- LA voters approved funding for an 8-mile bike path along the Los Angeles River nearly a decade ago, but construction still hasn't started.

-- Salmon are swimming up the Klamath River again, and sparking a new fight to keep them out of farmers' canals.

title: Newsom mounts a lonely stage at COP30
body:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom can add a new line to his resume after this month's climate talks in Brazil: unofficial U.S. climate ambassador.

The Democrat -- one of President Donald Trump's most prominent critics (and internet trolls) -- is the highest-ranking official representing the U.S. at the United Nations climate conference in Belm. But he's not there on behalf of the U.S. government.

"The reason I'm here is the absence of leadership coming from the United States," Newsom said today during an investor's symposium in So Paulo that coincided with the climate gathering, reports Camille von Kaenel. "This [leadership] vacuum is rather jaw dropping, not one representative -- not one, not even an observer, not someone taking notes -- that's going down to Belm."

Trump, who signed an order on his first day in office to withdraw the United States from the international Paris climate accord, has snubbed the gathering in Brazil. The administration said the president will instead engage with countries directly on his energy priorities (i.e., boosting fossil fuels and tearing down global climate goals).

The U.S. is the second largest greenhouse gas polluter behind China and was once the most powerful broker in international climate agreements. This year, not a single delegate from the federal government registered for the event.

America's absence was eerily felt amid the conference's bustling delegation offices, often indicators of global wealth and influence in the international climate sphere, where heavyweights like China and the European Union held court, reports POLITICO's Karl Mathiesen from Belm.

Trump officials aren't the only ones skipping this year's talks.

Sen. John Curtis (R-Utah), a mainstay of U.S. participation in previous years, is skipping the climate gathering this week because of the still-lingering government shutdown, while Senate Environment and Public Works ranking member Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.), a serial attender, was unsure if he'd make the trip, according to my colleague Amelia Davidson.

It's unclear what impact the U.S. absence will have on the climate talks, which take place as countries continue to fall short of their pollution-cutting targets and as global temperatures are on track to be the second- or third-warmest in recorded history. Already, coalitions like the European Union are facing new responsibility to step up, while some world leaders have slammed the Trump administration as "against mankind."

While in Belm, Newsom will meet with Jochen Flasbarth, undersecretary in the German Ministry of Environmental Affairs, and Thekla Walker, the environment minister in the German state of Baden-Wrttemberg, POLITICO's Josh Groeneveld reports from Berlin. Baden-Wrttemberg and California co-founded the climate initiative Under2 Coalition in 2015.

Newsom is not the first California governor to fill the U.S. seat at international climate talks when Washington interest wanes. His Democratic predecessor, Jerry Brown, got a warm greeting at the U.N. climate talks in 2017, during Trump's first term.

Speaking at the investors' conference Monday, Newsom said the U.S. is "doubling down on stupid" in an "ideological war" over climate. But he championed California as a "stable and reliable" partner for investors amid the country's larger backslide on its climate commitments.

Newsom said California is cultivating market interest -- to fill a multitrillion-dollar gap in investment needed for the energy transition -- through free enterprise and predictable regulation. But he also promised to speed up permitting, an area that's hindered clean energy progress, where the governor acknowledged, "We've gotten in our own way."

It's Monday -- thank you for tuning in to POLITICO's Power Switch. I'm your host, Heather Richards. Power Switch is brought to you by the journalists behind E&E News and POLITICO Energy. Send your tips, comments, questions to [email protected].

Today in POLITICO Energy's podcast: Josh Siegel and Kelsey Tamborrino break down how Democrats used energy as a campaign message.

Not it: Germany is hoping to avoid hosting the next U.N. climate talks by accident, write Karl Mathiesen and Zia Weise. The country is scrambling to solve a diplomatic dispute between Turkey and Australia, who both want to host the annual conference in 2026. If they don't find a resolution, Germany is obligated to step in under the rules of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change.

A trickle: Another 22 countries have submitted their overdue national climate plans, bringing the total to 86 out of the 195 parties to the Paris Agreement, Sara Schonhardt reports from Belm. Taken together, those new country-based climate targets would cut global climate pollution 12 percent by 2035 from 2019 levels -- still far below the 35 percent needed to meet the Paris goals.

Shutdown letdown

Federal energy and environmental workers are outraged over a deal to end the shutdown that doesn't include extending health care subsidies, write Robin Bravender, Kevin Bogardus, Hannah Northey and Michael Doyle.

Eight Senate Democrats voted Sunday to advance a stopgap funding bill -- a move that also wasn't appreciated by their House colleagues. The deal includes the promise of a separate Senate floor vote on the health care subsidies, leaving federal employees wondering why they endured furloughs and layoffs in the longest-ever shutdown in U.S. history.

"My people are generally aghast at what has happened," said Nicole Cantello, a union leader who represents employees in EPA's Chicago regional office. If federal workers and the American people "were going to suffer during the shutdown, they wanted to see more that was gotten for it than what's currently on the table."

The funding bill ensures that furloughed federal workers get back pay, forces the Trump administration to rehire employees it laid off during the shutdown and blocks more layoffs through Jan. 30.

Mission: Crush climate lawsuits

An attorney representing Exxon Mobil said defeating climate lawsuits against the oil company "is a big priority not just for Exxon Mobil, but for the entire industry," Lesley Clark writes.

"I didn't just move my family to Texas from the East Coast to have a bunch of activists and ambitious politicians bankrupt the company," Justin Anderson, Exxon's assistant general counsel for litigation, said during the Federalist Society's National Lawyers Convention in Washington. "We are not going to lose this fight."

Anderson is representing Exxon Mobil in its third attempt to get the Supreme Court to toss lawsuits from states and localities seeking compensation for climate change. The high court has already rebuffed similar efforts twice this year. Now, Anderson said, the court needs to step in "and decide once and for all that states are not empowered through their courts to regulate for the entire nation."

Bright spot: Houses with rooftop solar in Jamaica had electricity after Hurricane Melissa devastated the island's power grid.

Quiet on climate: Democrats have mentioned climate change far less this year, instead talking about energy affordability and security, according to a Washington Post analysis.

Oops: A blade broke off a wind turbine in Plymouth, Massachusetts, and landed in a cranberry bog Friday.

A showcase of some of our best subscriber content.

The impending shutdown deal is a stay of execution for the Interior Department employees whose jobs have been on the Trump administration's chopping block.

New Jersey Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill promised to freeze utility rates, but delivering on it will be a challenge.

A new study maps how artificial intelligence data centers could spike carbon emissions and stress water supplies through the end of the decade.

That's it for today, folks! Thanks for reading.

title: Greg Abbott, Gavin Newsom hold rallies in Texas 1 day apart
body: One day after California Gov. Gavin Newsom rallied in the Lone Star State, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott formally announced his reelection campaign. Dave Levinthal, contributing editor for NOTUS, and Brakkton Booker, national political correspondent for Politico, join "The Takeout" with analysis.

title: 'We feel alone': L.A. fire survivors call for California's insurance chief Lara to resign
body:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom is also facing pressure to oust Commissioner Ricardo Lara as insurance policyholders struggle with delayed and denied claims months after the Los Angeles fires.

Survivors of the deadly Los Angeles County fires, some of whom have been unable to rebuild because their insurance claims have been delayed or denied, are calling for California Insurance Commissioner Ricardo Lara to resign.

Lara, a former state lawmaker, has one year left in his second term.

Also see: California commissioner proposes insurance rule that critics call 'revenge'

A recent New York Times article detailing loopholes the insurance industry could exploit in Lara's plan to try to improve California insurance availability was the last straw, fire survivors said. They said it proved Lara has helped the insurance industry more than he has helped policyholders.

Lara and others said his plan, which officially rolled out just days before the L.A.-area fires in January, is in its early stages and will take time to work.

Jill Spivack, a State Farm policyholder whose home burned in the Palisades Fire, said during a press conference Thursday that she has been unable to rebuild.

Also see: Mercury seeks new home insurance rates using California's risk modeling system

"We feel alone, we feel forgotten," she said. She implored Gov. Gavin Newsom to replace Lara. "Californians deserve an insurance commissioner that protects families, not the insurers doing harm," Spivack said.

Lara -- who also faces accusations of improper spending of taxpayer dollars on travel -- told CalMatters in an interview that he has no plans to resign.

"I understand the anger (of fire victims)," Lara said. "I'm frustrated with the pace of recovery that involves multiple agencies, multiple levels of government."

He mentioned the actions he has taken in response, which include the Insurance Department's June launch of a formal investigation into State Farm over its handling of claims from the L.A.-area fires; a legal action against the FAIR Plan, the state's fire insurer of last resort; and a bulletin requiring insurance companies to fully investigate and pay smoke damage claims.

Lara's efforts aren't helping survivors quickly enough, some of them say. On a website the group recently launched calling for Lara's resignation, the Eaton Fire Survivors Network links to surveys that say 70% of policyholders face delays and denials, and that 61% expect to lose housing coverage within months. They want the investigations sped up. They want Lara to pause approvals of rate increases in the meantime.

Andrew Wessels is still waiting to move back into his Altadena home, which did not burn down but was damaged. He first spoke with CalMatters in May, as he was battling State Farm over getting his home tested for toxins because he did not want to move his two children back into a potentially unhealthy environment.

He told CalMatters on Friday that he is still waiting for more tests the insurer ordered as it decides what it wants to pay for. He expects to have to wait until next year before he and his family can actually rebuild. But he feels lucky that he, his wife and kids found semi-permanent housing after shuffling among Airbnbs since the fire. They are now three months into an 18-month lease that State Farm is paying for, and he's breathing a little easier because he's "not boxing up things every few weeks."

He is joining the call for Lara's resignation. He said the state's insurance department recently closed his complaint about State Farm's handling of his claims based on the company's word alone -- without asking him first.

"Recent information provided by the insurer states that the matter you originally brought to our attention is currently in stable condition," the department's Oct. 8 letter states.

"It was particularly concerning that it was closed without talking to me," Wessels said. "They're supposed to represent me. I think it speaks to who the Department of Insurance actually serves."

He appealed and asked a couple of his state lawmakers' staff to contact the department on his behalf, and it reopened his complaint.

"It was also concerning that 'if State Farm says it, it must be true,' since the department is investigating (the insurer) for illegal practices," Wessels added. That proves a change is needed, he said.

Newsom spokesperson Tara Gallegos and the governor's office did not return repeated requests for comment about the calls for the governor to replace Lara.

Nicole Ganley, a spokesperson for the American Property Casualty Insurance Association, said the industry group would have no comment on the effort to oust Lara. She pointed to a letter to the editor the group sent to the New York Times, which took issue with the story about insurers reportedly exploiting loopholes in the commissioner's new regulations by avoiding writing policies in certain areas, then turning around to request to raise their premiums anyway.

"The reforms are recent, and their impact is still unfolding," the letter says in part. "Suggesting failure at this stage misrepresents the facts and risks undermining public confidence in a strategy designed to stabilize coverage in high-risk areas."

Carmen Balber, executive director of Consumer Watchdog, the Los Angeles-based nonprofit organization that is often at odds with Lara, was also at the press conference. Throughout his tenure, her organization has questioned his insurance ties, beginning in 2019 when Lara received and returned campaign contributions from the industry. He ran for office pledging not to take money from companies he'd regulate.

The organization is also the main intervenor in insurance rate reviews, meaning it often submits challenges to insurers' proposed rate increases and changes. On Nov. 20, a public hearing is scheduled to discuss Lara's proposed changes to the intervenor process, which Consumer Watchdog has characterized as the commissioner's revenge.

"What we've seen happen over the past couple of years is things getting worse for consumers, not better," Balber told CalMatters ahead of the press conference. "We need someone new in charge who will hold the industry accountable to its promises."

But Amy Bach, executive director of San Francisco-based consumer advocacy group United Policyholders, said she is "sorry to see energy being expended in this direction."

She said there are legal, regulatory and other efforts underway to try to improve the state's home insurance market, and that bringing in a different commissioner isn't likely to speed things up. "There is no magic wand that will solve the insurance challenges that are plaguing L.A. wildfire survivors and causing premiums to rise untenably across the state," Bach said.

Robert Herrell, a former deputy insurance commissioner under Lara's predecessor, also used the magic-wand analogy. As climate disasters and risks proliferate, there is no easy fix to what ails property insurance in this state, nation and the rest of the world, he said.

Yet he said survivors need a strong commissioner who stands up to the insurance industry. "This is not that commissioner," said Herrell, who is now executive director of the nonprofit advocacy group Consumer Federation of California. "Just because he says that every time he takes action it's for the consumers doesn't make it true."

Bach said Lara has had to find a way to balance competing interests: "No prior commissioner faced the marketplace conditions he's faced, so it's hard to say whether a heavier-handed approach would have worked any better than what he's trying to achieve."

title: Democrats Trade Election Euphoria for Angst Over Shutdown Deal
body:
(Bloomberg) -- The decision by a group of Senate Democrats to vote to end the 41-day government shutdown -- after extracting no meaningful concessions from President Donald Trump -- has triggered outrage across much of the party.

Most Read from Bloomberg

California Governor Gavin Newsom decried the move as "a surrender," while Illinois Governor JB Pritzker dismissed it as an "empty promise" -- sentiments echoed across Capitol Hill and by party activists.

"Not a clue what they're thinking," said Amanda Litman, co-founder of the progressive nonprofit Run For Something, which has recruited thousands of people to run for office across the country. "Truly idiotic from top to bottom."

Some Democrats went beyond criticizing the deal itself to lambaste Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer of New York, who was perceived as failing to keep his caucus in line in a showdown his party might have won. Progressive Representative Ro Khanna of California said on X that Schumer "is no longer effective and should be replaced."

"If you can't lead the fight to stop healthcare premiums from skyrocketing for Americans, what will you fight for?" Khanna added.

Schumer said he would oppose the deal brokered by centrist members of his caucus with the Republican majority, but one of the moderates, Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, said Schumer had been kept informed as they negotiated.

As the standoff dragged on, Democrats seemed to have some momentum, with polls showing most of the public blaming Republicans for the longest shutdown in US history and airline cancellations piling up nationwide as Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy ordered flight cancellations. In addition, the administration's decision to take its fight to withhold billions in food aid all the way to the Supreme Court was a risky political gambit.

Some Democrats said last week's electoral victories showed that voters supported their shutdown fight. Trump himself even acknowledged the government closure hurt Republicans at the polls.

But the costs to key Democratic constituencies were also rising and the Trump administration showed little sign it was willing to consider the party's demands to extend health-care subsidies, even when Democrats offered to temper their proposal late last week.

title: Gavin Newsom's Texas 'victory lap' breaks faith with Californians...
body:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom received a hero's welcome from fellow Democrats in Texas this weekend after his victory in the Proposition 50 referendum.

The California ballot initiative passed overwhelmingly, despite the fact that it ripped power away from the public and placed it back in the hands of politicians -- i.e. Democrats -- to redraw congressional districts and eliminate the Republican opposition.

Newsom cast the vote in terms of national politics, telling Californians it was a way to push back against President Donald Trump, who remains unpopular in the state.

He also claimed his gerrymandering was a response to Texas Republicans, who redrew their own districts to comply with recent Supreme Court rulings that limited the use of race in district boundaries -- and eliminated five Democrat-held seats in the process.

Newsom, seen until now -- even within his own party -- as a slick, entitled politician, can now claim to have done more than any other Democrat to level the playing field ahead of the crucial 2026 midterm elections.

That, in turn, places him in a unique position to make his case for the party's presidential nomination in 2028.

Newsom excels in trolling Republicans -- which is why he hung around the GOP primary debates in 2023, and why he went to Texas this weekend to taunt the opposition.

But while he was gone, Californians continued to suffer the brunt of his policies.

Fire victims in Pacific Palisades and Altadena, for example, still endure endless delays -- both from insurance companies, which are reluctant to pay claims, and from local officials, who are dragging their feet in approving permits to rebuild.

Local residents, desperate for help, are calling for California Insurance Commissioner Ricardo Lara to resign, and demanding that Newsom ask him to step down.

The governor has yet to respond.

He is more concerned with what he calls the "de facto" end of the Trump presidency, which he promises will follow after the midterm elections.

How he hopes to convince Trump to approve $40 billion in requested federal fire aid after such antics is anyone's guess.

The state itself could help in any number of ways -- such as buying construction materials at discount bulk prices, which could lower costs for local families.

It could also develop long-term strategies to mitigate the danger of wildfires -- something Newsom has rejected in recent weeks, saying it would cost too much for a state that has struggled with budget deficits for the past two years.

Newsom has other priorities: He spent $282.6 million of public money on the special election for Prop 50.

Meanwhile, fuel is accumulating on public land -- like the land on which the Palisades Fire began, after being kindled from an earlier fire that state and local authorities failed to put out.

Newsom is taking a calculated gamble: That Democratic Party primary voters will care more about how vigorously a candidate fought the Trump administration than how well he or she performed in office.

For the sake of his political future, he'd better be right.

After nearly two terms in office as governor, following eight years as lieutenant governor and two terms as mayor of San Francisco, it is difficult to name a single real achievement in Newsom's long career.

He has simply failed upward.

The one thing Newsom has done well is to pick fights with Trump and with other Republicans, such as Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, usually over social issues.

Most of the country disagrees with Newsom's far-left positions on issues like transgenderism, such as a state law punishing school districts that inform parents of children's gender changes.

But Newsom knows his party is desperate for a candidate who can fight -- even one who leaves his own state behind.

title: The money burning a hole in Newsom's pocket
body:
CARRY THE ZERO -- Gov. Gavin Newsom's turn in the center of California's ballot spotlight may not yet be done.

By the end of the campaign to pass Proposition 50, Newsom's ballot-measure committee was so flush with cash that he was returning millions of dollars to the Democratic-aligned House Majority PAC and telling his supporters to "stop donating." But that could still leave Newsom with millions left in campaign funds earmarked for ballot-measure spending -- enough to shape debates over housing construction, taxes, insurance and tech regulation that are likely to be decided by voters next year.

Newsom has "a strong stake to have an impact on a California ballot campaign, although a fraction of what it often takes to win big contentious issues at the ballot box," said veteran ballot-measure consultant Ned Wigglesworth.

Newsom's committee, which spent about $17 million last year to pass the Prop 1 mental-health funding measure, had close to $6 million on hand when Newsom began promoting plans to sell voters on a gerrymander via constitutional amendment. Over barely two months, Newsom raised more than $83 million from both big and small donors and spent approximately $85 million on advertising.

The governor held over some money to cure ballots or fight legal challenges -- like the one Republicans launched the day after the election -- but has not made any plans for a 2026 campaign, a spokesperson said.

But the money is parked in an account that can't legally be used for some of Newsom's other political priorities -- like, say, trips to South Carolina -- and thus leaves Newsom another lever of influence in what is shaping up to be one of the busiest, most significant slate of initiatives presented to voters in recent years.

Should he choose to, there is no shortage of issues that Newsom could push over the finish line with his star power and resources. There's precedent for outgoing governors channeling their ballot accounts toward a capstone project: Near the end of his time in office, Gov. Jerry Brown funded Proposition 57 to undo the sentencing rules he'd enacted in his first go-around.

Newsom's labor allies are attempting to qualify a series of initiatives aiming to cap hospital CEO pay, regulate health clinic spending, and extend a tax on incomes of $250,000 or more. A high-stakes insurance fight will likely play out at the ballot. Further reform on the state's landmark environmental law, CEQA, which Newsom took the first stab at during the most recent legislative session, could also end up before voters.

And as Newsom prepares for a likely 2028 presidential run, he will have a political imperative to avoid haunting his campaign. Jim Steyer, the CEO of Common Sense Media, is attempting to qualify a measure that would regulate how young people use chatbots and prohibit companies from selling or sharing minors' data without consent, building off a bill that Newsom already vetoed (another potential line of attack for critics). He will have to navigate how an SEIU-UHW measure that would tax the state's billionaires would play in states like South Carolina.

"The governor has demonstrated the ability to raise huge dollars," said Wigglesworth, "so another California measure could be in the cards." -- With help from Jeremy B. White.

Welcome to Ballot Measure Weekly, a special edition of Playbook PM focused on California's lively realm of ballot-measure campaigns. Drop me a line at [email protected] or find me on X -- @wrmccart.

A highly subjective ranking of the ballot measures -- past and future, certain and possible -- getting our attention this week.

1. Voter ID (2026): The effort to qualify a ballot initiative that would require government-issued identification is continuing to cash in some significant checks, including $150,000 from Rep. Ken Calvert, a California Republican whose political future has been put in jeopardy by Prop 50's passage. Over the weekend, the campaign announced that they had gathered 500,000 signatures, more than half of the approximately 874,000 they'll need to earn a spot on the 2026 ballot.

2. Scientific research bond (2026): A coalition is forming to fill the void left by federal cuts to scientific research funding. Supporters of the $23 billion bond, including state Sen. Scott Wiener and UAW members were planning to gather in San Francisco earlier in the day in the unofficial launch to their campaign to get the measure on the ballot via SB 607, a bill introduced in February.

3. Independent redistricting (2026): Conservative attorney and author James Lacy has filed an initiative that would effectively repeal Proposition 50 after one election cycle and reimpose maps drawn by California's independent redistricting commission starting with the 2028 election. Although Lacy has hired staff, he has not yet secured coalition or fundraising commitments, telling Playbook "if you build it, they will come."

4. Bay Area transit tax (2026): A campaign to fund transit systems in the Bay Area is attempting to qualify its measure for the 2026 ballot via a citizen's initiative, which lowers the threshold for passage from two-thirds to a simple majority. Internal polling for the measure shows support hovering around 56 percent -- above a majority but below the two-thirds threshold.

5. Measure A (Santa Clara County, 2025): A sales-tax increase approved in the South Bay last Tuesday is expected to generate more than $1.5 billion to keep county-owned hospitals running even after federal cuts, our Rachel Bluth reports. The measure had been watched closely by health officials around the state, and organizers in Los Angeles County, Alameda and other Bay Area counties are weighing similar proposals.

6. Tax CEOs (San Francisco, 2026): San Francisco voters will have the chance to go after the vast resources of some of their wealthiest residents through two local measures likely to appear on the 2026 ballot. The measures, one led by county supervisors and the second by local progressive groups, both aim to raise money for the general fund.

7. Top earner tax (2026): A CTA-led proposal to make permanent a tax on incomes over $250,000 has been cleared for circulation. Proponents will now have until early May to collect 874,000 signatures to qualify the measure for the 2026 ballot, and have already been seeded with an initial $5 million to launch the effort.

FINAL STRETCH -- With an end to the government shutdown finally in sight, California Reps. Sam Liccardo, a Democrat, and Kevin Kiley, a Republican, introduced a bill today that would extend expiring Affordable Care Act tax credits for two years following a Senate vote on Sunday that advanced a key plan to break the shutdown stalemate, our reporters on the Hill write.

The legislation comes as many progressives in the Senate, as well as a large number of House Democrats, think that any deal that doesn't extend ACA credits isn't sufficient. Democratic leadership in the House has stressed that health subsidies be addressed in the bill over a handshake compromise.

The bipartisan bill from Liccardo and Kiley breaks with other similar legislation -- like Virginia Rep. Jen Kiggans' bill -- that would enact a clean extension. Instead, eligibility for credits would be capped for those who make six times the poverty-level income, which would be $192,900 for a family of four. To "pay for" the bill, the legislation would target "upcoding" in Medicare Advantage and crack down on insurance brokers who submit false enrollment applications.

"Our bipartisan legislation will assure Americans are spared from a massive increase in healthcare costs that is just around the corner," Kiley said in a statement, adding that the legislation will "provide short-term relief while we tackle broader reforms to lower the cost of care."

-- The California Supreme Court upheld a law that protects the rights of gay and transgender people in nursing homes and prohibits staff from misgendering residents. (Los Angeles Times)

-- As the state figures out how to regrow tens of thousands of trees hit by fires or disease, it also grapples with another challenge: finding enough people willing to climb trees and gather seeds. (SF Standard)

-- Republicans' and Democrats' redistricting push is reminiscent of 19th-century partisan map-drawing schemes that ultimately backfired as politicians pressed their advantages too far. (POLITICO)

title: Democrats Trade Election Euphoria for Angst Over Shutdown Deal
body:
The decision by a group of Senate Democrats to vote to end the 41-day government shutdown -- after extracting no meaningful concessions from President Donald Trump -- has triggered outrage across much of the party.

California Governor Gavin Newsom decried the move as "a surrender," while Illinois Governor JB Pritzker dismissed it as an "empty promise" -- sentiments echoed across Capitol Hill and by party activists.

title: Exclusive--Zeldin on Palisades Fires: Karen Bass and Gavin Newsom Need to 'Get Off of Their Asses'
body:
Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass (D) and California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) need to "get off their asses," EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin said during a policy event with Breitbart News on Monday, discussing the aftermath of the devastating fire in the Palisades.

Describing the aftermath in the Palisades as "apocalyptic," with over 13,000 buildings destroyed, Zeldin said his agency quickly jumped in to do their part.

"In record time this happened, the middle of January. [The] President was sworn in. A few days later, he signed an executive order. He wanted EPA to finish our Phase One hazardous material removal in 30 days, so that Army Corps can come in and do their Phase Two debris removal. The initial response was that was going to be impossible. You'll be lucky if you could get this done by the summer, and we got it done in Trump speed, and got it done in less than 30 days," Zeldin said, giving a big thank you to the EPA team and their staffers who were "busting their tails to help the good people of Los Angeles who lost everything."

WATCH -- Lee Zeldin: Trump's EPA 'Leaning into Innovation' Instead of Overregulation to Protect Environment:

Ultimately, he said their work was completed in that timeline, and the Army Corps has since completed Phase Two debris removal.

"So, as far as the federal government goes, we completed all of our work. Now this might be a little bit less politically correct," he said before tearing into local leaders.
